column21: Raise occupies a pivotal position on the Helvellyn ridge
column22: marking the point where the main ridge from Helvellyn turns northward toward Stybarrow Dodd and the Dodds. The fell derives its name from the Old Norse "hreysi" meaning a cairn or pile of stones. Most walkers encounter Raise while traversing the Helvellyn ridge
column23: with direct approaches possible from Sticks Pass which crosses the fell's eastern shoulder and has served as an important route between the valleys since Norse times. The summit features a trig point and offers excellent views toward Ullswater and the Far Eastern Fells
column24: with particularly impressive perspectives of Helvellyn's northern face. The eastern slopes are home to the Lake District Ski Club
column25: established in 1936 and operating a modest ski tow when conditions permit
column26: making Raise the only fell in the range to offer organized winter sports. The predominantly grassy upper slopes give way to steeper
column27: rockier terrain on the eastern face above Keppel Cove
column28: where a now-abandoned reservoir dam once supplied water to Glenridding's lead mines. The western flanks descend more gently toward Glencoyne
column29: offering easy walking through typical Lakeland grassland dotted with outcrops of rock.

column21: Coniston Old Man stands as the highest point of the Furness Fells
column22: its distinctive profile dominating the skyline above Coniston village and lake. The mountain has a rich industrial heritage
column23: with extensive copper mines on its eastern flanks dating back to Elizabethan times and slate quarrying that continued well into the 20th century. Most walkers approach from Coniston village via the well-established "tourist route" past the disused copper mines
column24: though alternative paths exist from Walna Scar Road to the south or via the connecting ridge from Swirl How to the north. The summit features a trig point and stone wind shelter
column25: offering spectacular panoramic views across the southern Lake District to Morecambe Bay
column26: with particularly impressive perspectives of Dow Crag's eastern face across the dramatic glacial cirque of Goat's Water. The predominantly rocky upper slopes support limited vegetation
column27: mainly hardy montane species adapted to the harsh conditions
column28: while the lower slopes feature areas of heather moorland and eventually give way to bracken and the ancient deciduous woodland that lines the shores of Coniston Water. The Old Man features prominently in Arthur Ransome's "Swallows and Amazons" books as "Kanchenjunga

a mysterious mountain that the children aspire to climb.
2396,Sail,Lake District - North Western Fells,EL02 Gable-grasmoor,Cumberland,Sim
column50: Sail derives its evocative name from the Old Norse "segl" meaning a sail
column51: aptly describing its distinctive profile when viewed from certain angles in the Newlands Valley. The fell forms part of the ridge connecting Crag Hill to Causey Pike
column52: creating a dramatic skyline visible from Keswick and the surrounding valleys. Most walkers encounter Sail while traversing the Coledale Horseshoe
column53: with direct approaches possible from Rigg Beck in Newlands or from the Coledale valley to the north. The summit
column54: marked by a simple cairn on a grassy dome
column55: offers excellent views across the Northwestern Fells with particularly impressive perspectives of Crag Hill's precipitous eastern face. The eastern slopes have been dramatically altered by extensive erosion caused by heavy foot traffic
column56: leading to a major restoration project by Fix the Fells that replaced the eroded "vertical mile" with a more sustainable zigzag path. The predominantly grassy terrain supports hardy upland sheep grazing
column57: with few rocky features to break the smooth contours that characterize much of this section of the Northwestern Fells. Despite its modest height compared to some neighbors
column58: Sail's distinctive profile and central position make it an important component of one of the Lake District's most popular and scenic ridge walks.

column17: higher ground NW of summit cairn
column21: St Sunday Crag rises dramatically above Patterdale
column22: its impressive northeastern face presenting a series of formidable crags that contrast with the gentler southwestern slopes. The fell's unusual name likely derives from "Sunnen's Crag
column23:
named after a now-forgotten Norse settler, later altered by Christian influence. Most walkers approach from Patterdale via the path to Grisedale Tarn before ascending the steep southeastern ridge, or via the connecting ridge from Fairfield as part of the popular Deepdale Horseshoe route. The summit plateau features a cairn, though slightly higher ground can be found just northwest, offering spectacular views across Ullswater and toward the Helvellyn range, with particularly impressive perspectives of Fairfield's northern face. The northeastern slopes drop precipitously toward Grisedale through a series of imposing crags that provide challenging scrambling and climbing routes, while the southwestern flanks descend more gradually toward Deepdale. The predominantly rocky upper slopes support limited vegetation, mainly hardy montane species, while the lower reaches feature areas of heather and bilberry that give way to bracken and eventually the ancient deciduous woodland that clings to the lower Grisedale valley. The fell's distinctive profile and excellent summit views make it a popular objective despite the steep ascent required from most directions.
2398,Whiteless Pike,Lake District - North Western Fells,EL02 Gable-grasmoor,Cumberland,Sim
column44: Whiteless Pike presents a distinctive pointed profile when viewed from Buttermere village
column45: forming the southern sentinel of the range connecting to Wandope and Crag Hill. The fell's name likely derives from the pale
column46: grassy eastern slopes that appear almost white in certain light conditions
column47: particularly when the surrounding terrain is in shadow. Most walkers approach from Buttermere via the clearly defined ridge ascending from Whiteless Breast
column48: or as part of a traverse from Wandope to Rannerdale Knotts. The rocky summit
column50: offers exceptional panoramic views across Buttermere and Crummock Water to the High Stile range
column51: with particularly impressive perspectives down the length of the Buttermere valley. The eastern slopes drop steeply toward Rannerdale

column53: while the lower reaches feature bracken and scattered rowans and hawthorns in the more sheltered gullies. Despite its modest height compared to neighboring peaks
